topic: RATINGS INFORMATION SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
question: (Now, I'd like to rate your feelings toward some people and organizations, with one hundred making a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and fifty meaning not particularly warm or cold. You can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number the more favorable your feelings are toward that person or organization. If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...Gay marriage...Give...gay marriage a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. (If Don't know, ask:)Would you say you are unable to give an opinion of...gay marriage, or have you never heard of...gay marriage?
description:
Survey by Democracy Corps.
Methodology: Conducted by Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research, October 21 - October 24, 2016 and based on     900 telephone interviews. Sample: National likely voters. Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2012 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably/almost certain/50-50 to vote in the 2016 election. [USGREEN.102516.R24] (View Citation)
Topics: RATINGS INFORMATION SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
Formal Citation
Democracy Corps. Democracy Corps Poll,
Oct, 2016 [survey question]. USGREEN.102516.R24. Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Warm 51-100': ' 51%', 'Cool 0-49': ' 31%', 'Not particularly warm or cold-50': ' 15%', "Never heard of/Don't know/Refused": '  3%'}

If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...Gay marriage...Give...gay marriage, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. (If Don't know, ask:)Would you say you are unable to give an opinion of...gay marriage, or have you never heard of...gay marriage?

If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...Gay marriage...Give...gay marriage a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. (If Don't know, ask:)Would you say you are unable to give an opinion of...gay marriage, or have you never heard of...gay marriage?

description:
Survey by Common Cause, Change Congress, Public Campaign Action Fund.
Methodology: Conducted by Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research, February 2 - February 4, 2010 and based on     805 telephone interviews. Sample: National likely voters. Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2006 and 2008 elections/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2010 election. [USGREEN.10COMCS.R17] (View Citation)

If you have no opinion or never heard of that person or organization please say so.)...Gay marriage...Give...gay marriage a rating, with 100 meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and 50 meaning not particularly warm or cold. (If Don't know, ask:)Would you say you are unable to give an opinion of...gay marriage, or have you never heard of...gay marriage?
description:
Survey by Democracy Corps.
Methodology: Conducted by Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research, March 16 - March 20, 2006 and based on   1,150 telephone interviews. Sample: National likely voters. National likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2004 presidential election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote, and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2006 election. [USGREEN.06DCMAR16.R18] (View Citation)
Topics: RATINGS INFORMATION SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
Formal Citation
Democracy Corps. Democracy Corps Poll,
Mar, 2006 [survey question]. USGREEN.06DCMAR16.R18. Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.

source: Public Religion Research Institute Hispanic Values Survey, September 2013
question: We would like to get your views on some issues that are being discussed in the country today.  Do you strongly favor, favor, oppose, or strongly oppose the following?...Allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry legally
description:
Survey by PRRI.
Methodology: Conducted by Public Religion Research Institute, August 23 - September 3, 2013 and based on   1,563 online interviews. Sample: National adult Hispanics. Funding was provided by the Ford Foundation and the New World Foundation. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to self-select into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USPRRI.092713H.R12A] (View Citation)
Topics: HISPANICS SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY

question: Do you strongly favor, favor, oppose or strongly oppose...allowing gays and lesbians to marry legally?
url: https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/CFIDE/cf/action/ipoll/questionDetail.cfm?keyword=(gay% or {same sex} or homosexual%) and marr%&keywordoptions=1&exclude=&excludeOptions=1&topic=Any&organization=Any&label=&fromdate=1/1/1935&toDate=&stitle=&sponsor=Pew Research Center for the People & the Press, Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life&studydate=June 28-July 10, 2012&sample=2973&qstn_list=&qstnid=1814770&qa_list=&qstn_id4=1814770&study_list=&lastSearchId=317673332532&archno=USPEW2012-RELIG&keywordDisplay=
description:
DOWNLOAD DATASET
ANALYZE DATASET
Survey by Pew Research Center for the People & the Press, Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life.
Methodology: Conducted by Princeton Survey Research Associates International, June 28 - July 9, 2012 and based on   2,973 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult. 1771 respondents were interviewed on a landline telephone, and 1202 were interviewed on a cell phone, including 596 who had no landline telephone.  The questions in this report were developed in consultation with Religion and Ethics NewsWeekly.  In partnership with Religion and Ethics NewsWeekly the Pew Forum conducted an additional 511 interviews with religiously unaffiliated adults to produce a total sample of 958 unaffiliated respondents.  The additional 511 interviews were conducted June 28-July 10, 2012 with religiously unaffiliated adults recruited by screening respondents from a fresh sample of landline and cell phone (261 interviews), and by recontacting respondents from recent surveys who had identified themselves as religiously unaffiliated (250 interviews).  These interviews are not used in the results reported for the general public here. [USPSRA.073112R.R30A] (View Citation)
Topics: SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
Dataset: USPEW2012-RELIG

source: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll, October 2014
question: (How important are each of the following issues to you personally?...Extremely important, very important, moderately important, slightly important, not at all important)...Same-sex marriage
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, October 16 - October 20, 2014 and based on   1,608 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.102114G.R09E] (View Citation)
Topics: PROBLEMS SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
Formal Citation
Associated Press. Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll,
Oct, 2014 [survey question]. USAP.102114G.R09E. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Extremely important': ' 16%', 'Very important': ' 13%', 'Moderately important': ' 23%', 'Slightly important': ' 16%', 'Not at all important': ' 31%', 'Refused/Not answered': '  1%'}

description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, April 23 - April 27, 2015 and based on   1,077 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.042915G.R04] (View Citation)
Topics: SEX GROUPS EQUALITY FAMILY
Formal Citation
Associated Press. Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll,
Apr, 2015 [survey question]. USAP.042915G.R04. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.

Center for Public Opinion Research.

question: (Now, we would like to get your views on some issues that are being discussed in the country today. Do you favor or oppose the following?)...Allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry legally
description:
Survey by Brookings Institution.
Methodology: Conducted by PRRI, April 4 - May 2, 2016 and based on   2,607 telephone and online interviews. Sample: National adult. 2146 respondents were interviewed online, and 461 by telephone.
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national U.S. adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORCs AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States. [USPRRI.062316.R13B] (View Citation)
Topics: SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY PROBLEMS
Formal Citation
Brookings Institution. PRRI/Brookings Immigration Survey,
Apr, 2016 [survey question]. USPRRI.062316.R13B. PRRI [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Strongly favor': ' 32%', 'Favor': ' 30%', 'Oppose': ' 18%', 'Strongly oppose': ' 18%', "Don't know/Refused": '  2%'}

sample: National adults age 18-35 including oversamples of African-Americans, Hispanics, and Asian-Pacific Islanders
question: We would like to get your views on some issues that are being discussed in the country today. Do you favor or oppose the following?...Allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry legally
description:
DOWNLOAD DATASET
Survey by PRRI.
Methodology: Conducted by Public Religion Research Institute, February 12 - February 25, 2015 and based on   2,314 online interviews. Sample: National adults age 18-35 including oversamples of African-Americans, Hispanics, and Asian-Pacific Islanders. Results were weighted to be representative of a national adult sample.  Funding was provided by the Ford Foundation. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USPRRI.032715.R04A] (View Citation)
Topics: SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
Dataset: USPRRI2015-MSRH
Formal Citation
PRRI. PRRI Millennials, Sexuality, and Reproductive Health Survey,
Feb, 2015 [survey question]. USPRRI.032715.R04A. Public Religion Research Institute [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.

Methodology: Conducted by Public Religion Research Institute, September 21 - October 3, 2013 and based on   2,317 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to 'self-select' into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week.

url: https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/CFIDE/cf/action/ipoll/questionDetail.cfm?keyword=(gay% or {same sex} or homosexual%) and marr%&keywordoptions=1&exclude=&excludeOptions=1&topic=Any&organization=Any&label=&fromdate=1/1/1935&toDate=&stitle=&sponsor=Public Religion Research Institute&studydate=February 23-March 5, 2012&sample=1004&qstn_list=&qstnid=1808434&qa_list=&qstn_id4=1808434&study_list=&lastSearchId=317673332532&archno=USPRRI2012-JVS&keywordDisplay=
description:
DOWNLOAD DATASET
ANALYZE DATASET
Survey by Public Religion Research Institute.
Methodology: Conducted by Public Religion Research Institute, February 23 - March 5, 2012 and based on   1,004 online interviews. Sample: National adult Jewish Americans. Interviews were conducted by Knowledge Networks using its national panel which is randomly selected from the entire national population and subsequently provided Internet access, if needed.  Only self-identified Jewish Americans were interviewed.  The population of Jewish Americans was determined by using two separate screening questions that were designed to identify the Core Jewish Population, a category with a long history in Jewish demography, consisting of self-identifying Jews by religion and persons who consider themselves Jewish (e.g., ethnically or culturally) but who claim no religion.  The results were weighted to Interviews were conducted by Knowledge Networks using its national panel which is randomly selected from the entire national population and subsequently provided Internet access, if needed.  Only self-identified Jewish Americans were interviewed.  The population of Jewish Americans was determined by using two separate screening questions that were designed to identify the Core Jewish Population, a category with a long history in Jewish demography, consisting of self-identifying Jews by religion and persons who consider themselves Jewish (e.g., ethnically or culturally) but who claim no religion.  The results were weighted to be representative of a national adult Jewish American sample.  The survey was funded by the Nathan Cummings Foundation. [USPRRI.12JEWVAL.R21A] (View Citation)

source: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll, October 2014
question: Should couples of the same sex be entitled to the same government benefits as married couples of the opposite sex, or should the government distinguish between them?
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, October 16 - October 20, 2014 and based on   1,608 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.103014G.R07] (View Citation)

source: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll, April 2015
question: ((If Same-sex marriage legal in respondent's state, ask:)Do you.../(All others, ask:)Would you favor, oppose, or neither favor nor oppose a law allowing same-sex couples to be legally married in your state? Would you say you favor a law allowing same-sex couples to be legally married in your state strongly or just somewhat? Would you say you oppose a law allowing same-sex couples to be legally married in your state strongly or just somewhat?)(If Neither/Refused, ask:)If you had to choose, do you lean more toward favoring or opposing a law allowing same-sex couples to be legally married in your state?
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, April 23 - April 27, 2015 and based on   1,077 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.042915G.R05] (View Citation)
Topics: SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
Formal Citation
Associated Press. Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll,
Apr, 2015 [survey question]. USAP.042915G.R05. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Strongly favor': ' 34%', 'Somewhat favor': '  5%', 'Lean toward favoring': '  9%', 'Neither favor nor oppose': ' 14%', 'Lean toward opposing': '  6%', 'Somewhat oppose': '  5%', 'Strongly oppose': ' 25%', 'Refused/Not answered': '  2%'}

source: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll, October 2015
topic: STATES LOCAL GOVERNMENT RELIGION SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
question: Do you think that state and local officials and judges who issue marriage licenses  but have religious objections to same-sex marriage should be required to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, or should they be exempt from issuing them?
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, October 15 - October 19, 2015 and based on   1,027 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.103015G.R03] (View Citation)
Topics: STATES LOCAL GOVERNMENT RELIGION SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
Formal Citation
Associated Press. Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll,
Oct, 2015 [survey question]. USAP.103015G.R03. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Exempt from issuing them': ' 41%', 'Required to issue them': ' 56%', 'Refused': '  3%'}

Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, March 20 - March 24, 2014 and based on   1,012 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.040514G.R05F] (View Citation)
Topics: PARTIES PROBLEMS SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
Formal Citation
Associated Press. Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll,
Mar, 2014 [survey question]. USAP.040514G.R05F. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'The Democratic Party': ' 31%', 'The Republican Party': ' 17%', 'Both equally': ' 17%', 'Neither': ' 32%', 'Refused/Not answered': '  2%'}

topic: VOTE FOR PRESIDENT ELECTIONS CONGRESS PROBLEMS
sample: National likely voters including an oversample of battleground state voters
question: Which of the following types of issues are most likely to affect your vote for President and Congress this year (2012)-- economic issues like jobs and unemployment, fiscal issues like taxes, spending, deficits, and debt, social issues like abortion and gay marriage, or national security issues like terrorism and Afghanistan?
description:
Survey by Resurgent Republic.
Methodology: Conducted by North Star Opinion Research, August 16 - August 22, 2012 and based on   1,000 telephone interviews. Sample: National likely voters including an oversample of battleground state voters. Interviews were conducted by landline and cell phones.  Likely voters are registered voters who said they are absolutely certain/very likely/somewhat likely to vote in the 2012 election.  The survey included 1000 likely voters including an oversample to reach a total of 462 voters in 12 battleground states: Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Michigan, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Mexico, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Wisconsin.  Results were weighted to be representative of a national likely voters population. [USAYRES.12RESREPAUG.R02] (View Citation)
Topics: VOTE FOR PRESIDENT ELECTIONS CONGRESS PROBLEMS
Formal Citation
Resurgent Republic. Resurgent Republic Survey,
Aug, 2012 [survey question]. USAYRES.12RESREPAUG.R02. North Star Opinion Research [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Economic issues': ' 53%', 'Fiscal issues': ' 23%', 'Social issues': ' 12%', 'National security issues': '  5%', "None/Other (Vol.)/Don't know": '  6%'}

source: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll, April 2015
topic: SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY BUSINESS RELIGION
question: In states where same-sex couples can be married legally, do you think that businesses with religious objections should be allowed to refuse service to same-sex couples, or not?
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, April 23 - April 27, 2015 and based on   1,077 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.042915G.R09] (View Citation)
Topics: SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY BUSINESS RELIGION
Formal Citation
Associated Press. Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll,
Apr, 2015 [survey question]. USAP.042915G.R09. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Yes, they should be allowed to refuse service': ' 40%', 'No, they should not be allowed to refuse service': ' 57%', 'Refused': '  3%'}

source: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll, October 2014
topic: SEX GROUPS EQUALITY FAMILY STATES GOVERNMENT
question: Do you think making laws about marriages between couples of the same sex should be the responsibility of state governments or the responsibility of the federal government?
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, October 16 - October 20, 2014 and based on   1,608 telephone interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.103014G.R11] (View Citation)
Topics: SEX GROUPS EQUALITY FAMILY STATES GOVERNMENT
Formal Citation

Oct, 2014 [survey question]. USAP.103014G.R11. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].

Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'State governments': ' 52%', 'The federal government': ' 44%', 'Refused/Not answered': '  4%'}

source: Virginia Slims American Women's Poll 1995, March 1995
question: In today's society there are many different lifestyles, and some that are acceptable today that weren't in the past. Regardless of what you may have done or plan to do with your life, and thinking just of what would give you personally the most satisfying and interesting life, which one of these different ways of life do you think would be the best as a way of life? A traditional marriage with the husband assuming the responsibility for providing for the family and the wife running the house and taking care of the children, a marriage where the husband and wife share responsibilities more, both work, both share homemaking and child responsibilities, living with someone of the opposite sex, but not marrying, remaining single and living alone, remaining single and living with others of the same sex, living in a big family of people with similar interests, in which some of the people are married and some are not.

question: (Do you favor, oppose, or neither favor nor oppose a law allowing same-sex couples to be legally married in your state? Would you say you favor a law allowing same-sex couples to be legally married in your state strongly or just somewhat? Would you say you oppose a law allowing same-sex couples to be legally married in your state strongly or just somewhat?)(If Neither/Refused, ask:)If you had to choose, do you lean more toward favoring or opposing a law allowing same-sex couples to be legally married in your state?
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, October 15 - October 19, 2015 and based on   1,027 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.103015G.R02] (View Citation)
Topics: SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
Formal Citation
Associated Press. Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll,
Oct, 2015 [survey question]. USAP.103015G.R02. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.

source: Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll, April 2015
question: As you may know, the Supreme Court will hear a case this year (2015)on whether state laws banning same-sex couples from marrying are constitutional. Do you think that the Supreme Court should or should not rule that same-sex marriage must be legal nationwide?
description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, April 23 - April 27, 2015 and based on   1,077 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.042915G.R06] (View Citation)
Topics: GROUPS SEX FAMILY EQUALITY COURTS
Formal Citation
Associated Press. Associated Press/GfK Knowledge Networks Poll,
Apr, 2015 [survey question]. USAP.042915G.R06. GfK Knowledge Networks [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Should': ' 50%', 'Should not': ' 48%', 'Refused': '  3%'}

source: Pew Research Center's American Trends Panel Poll, September 2016
survey_by: Pew Research Center for the People & the Press
topic: BUSINESS SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY RIGHTS RELIGION
question: (As you may know, same-sex marriage is now legal in all 50 states. Some argue that businesses that provide wedding-related services, such as catering or flowers, should be able to refuse to provide those services to same-sex couples if the business owner has religious objections to homosexuality. Others argue that businesses that provide wedding-related services should be required to provide those services to same-sex couples just as they would to all other customers. We're interested in your views about this situation.)...And if you had to choose, which comes closest to your view? Businesses that provide wedding services, such as catering or flowers should be able to refuse to provide those services to same-sex couples if the business owner has religious objections to homosexuality, or required to provide those services to same-sex couples just as they would to all other customers?
url: https://ropercenter.cornell.edu/CFIDE/cf/action/ipoll/questionDetail.cfm?keyword=(gay% or {same sex} or homosexual%) and marr%&keywordoptions=1&exclude=&excludeOptions=1&topic=Any&organization=Any&label=&fromdate=1/1/1935&toDate=&stitle=&sponsor=Pew Research Center for the People & the Press&studydate=01-JAN-34&sample=4538&qstn_list=&qstnid=1885780&qa_list=&qstn_id4=1885780&study_list=&lastSearchId=317673332532&archno=&keywordDisplay=
description:
Survey by Pew Research Center for the People & the Press.
Methodology: Conducted by Abt SRBI, August 16 - September 12, 2016 and based on   4,538 online, telephone, and mail interviews. Sample: National adult. 4195 respondents were interviewed online and 343 by telephone or mail. The American Trends Panel (ATP), created by the Pew Research Center, is a nationally representative panel of randomly selected US adults living in households. Respondents who self-identify as Internet users (representing 89% of US adults) participate in the panel via monthly self-administered Web surveys, and those who do not use the Internet participate via telephone or mail. description:
Survey by Yale University Project on Climate Change Communication, George Mason University Center for Climate Change Communication.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, March 18 - March 31, 2016 and based on   1,004 online interviews. Sample: National registered voters. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to 'self-select' into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. Funding was provided by the 11th Hour Project, the Energy Foundation, the Grantham Foundation, and the V.K. Rasmussen Foundation. [USKN.042516CC.R06W] (View Citation)

description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, December 11 - December 13, 2015 and based on   1,020 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the US adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 US households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the US. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.122615G.R09E] (View Citation)
Topics: COURTS SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY STATES
Formal Citation

Center for Public Opinion Research.

description:
Survey by PRRI.
Methodology: Conducted by Public Religion Research Institute, September 11 - October 4, 2015 and based on   2,695 telephone and online interviews. Sample: National adult. 2297 respondents were interviewed online, and 398 by telephone.
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national U.S. adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. description:
Survey by Associated Press.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, July 9 - July 13, 2015 and based on   1,004 online interviews. Sample: National adult. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel. The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USAP.071815G.R03] (View Citation)

description:
Survey by Harvard Institute of Politics.
Methodology: Conducted by GfK Knowledge Networks, March 18 - April 1, 2015 and based on   3,034 online interviews. Sample: National adult age 18-29. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to "self-select" into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USKN.042915IOP.R030] (View Citation)
Topics: VOTE FOR PRESIDENT SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY

topic: HISPANICS PROBLEMS GROUPS SEX FAMILY EQUALITY
question: Thinking about some issues in the country today, please read the issues below and indicate whether you think it is a critical issue facing the country, one among many important issues, or not that important compared to other issues....Same-sex marriage
description:
Survey by PRRI.
Methodology: Conducted by Public Religion Research Institute, August 23 - September 3, 2013 and based on   1,563 online interviews. Sample: National adult Hispanics. Funding was provided by the Ford Foundation and the New World Foundation. The poll was fielded by GfK Knowledge Networks using its national KnowledgePanel.  The KnowledgePanel is a nationally representative probability sample of the U.S. adult population. Panelists are recruited by randomly selecting residential addresses using a process called address-based sampling (ABS). Since nearly 3-in-10 U.S. households do not have home Internet access, respondent households who do not have Internet access or own a computer are provided Internet service and a netbook computer to ensure that panel respondents are representative of the U.S. adult population. Unlike opt-in panels, households are not permitted to self-select into KnowledgePanel; nor are they allowed to participate in many surveys per week. [USPRRI.092713H.R11A] (View Citation)
Topics: HISPANICS PROBLEMS GROUPS SEX FAMILY EQUALITY
Formal Citation
PRRI. Public Religion Research Institute Hispanic Values Survey,
Aug, 2013 [survey question]. USPRRI.092713H.R11A. Public Religion Research Institute [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Critical issue': ' 22%', 'One among many': ' 34%', 'Not that important': ' 42%', 'Refused': '  3%'}

topic: SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY STATES GOVERNMENT CONGRESS REFORM
question: Next, we want to get your opinion of the issues related to gay rights that Washington is now considering.  As you may know, laws relating to marriage have traditionally been handled by individual states, not the federal government.  But some believe Washington should set uniform national laws about whether marriages between individuals of the same gender should be recognized.  On the issue of same sex marriage, would you prefer Congress pass a constitutional amendment to ban same sex marriage in every state regardless of state law, pass a constitutional amendment to permit same sex marriage in every state regardless of state law, or take no action and let each state decide whether to permit or ban same sex marriage?

Survey by Public Religion Research Institute.
Methodology: Conducted by Public Religion Research Institute, February 23 - March 5, 2012 and based on   1,004 online interviews. Sample: National adult Jewish Americans. Interviews were conducted by Knowledge Networks using its national panel which is randomly selected from the entire national population and subsequently provided Internet access, if needed.  Only self-identified Jewish Americans were interviewed.  The population of Jewish Americans was determined by using two separate screening questions that were designed to identify the Core Jewish Population, a category with a long history in Jewish demography, consisting of self-identifying Jews by religion and persons who consider themselves Jewish (e.g., ethnically or culturally) but who claim no religion.  The results were weighted to Interviews were conducted by Knowledge Networks using its national panel which is randomly selected from the entire national population and subsequently provided Internet access, if needed. The population of Jewish Americans was determined by using two separate screening questions that were designed to identify the Core Jewish Population, a category with a long history in Jewish demography, consisting of self-identifying Jews by religion and persons who consider themselves Jewish (e.g., ethnically or culturally) but who claim no religion.  The results were weighted to be representative of a national adult Jewish American sample.  The survey was funded by the Nathan Cummings Foundation. [USPRRI.12JEWVAL.R02] (View Citation)

source: Third Way Marriage Equality Survey, March 2009
sample: National likely voters including an oversample of blacks
question: Regardless of whether you support allowing gay and lesbian couples to adopt children, here are some arguments some people have made as to why they oppose allowing gay and lesbian couples to adopt children.  Please tell me which one or two arguments are most convincing to you....Girls need female role models and boys need male role models.  If more kids are raised by gay parents, I worry that children may think it's OK to experiment with homosexuality.  Children raised by gay parents would be teased and bullied at school.  Pro-gay activists are trying to put their own agenda ahead of what is best for children.  Allowing gay people to adopt will be the first step to allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry.
description:
Survey by Third Way.
Methodology: Conducted by Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research, January 13 - January 18, 2009 and based on     917 telephone interviews. Sample: National likely voters including an oversample of blacks. There was a total of 139 African American respondents.  Results were weighted to be representative of a national likely voters population.  Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2008 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2010 election.  There were also parallel surveys in California and Arkansas November 5-11, 2008. [USGREEN.09THIRDMAR.R39] (View Citation)
Topics: SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
Formal Citation
Third Way. Third Way Marriage Equality Survey,
Jan, 2009 [survey question]. USGREEN.09THIRDMAR.R39. Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Girls need female role models and boys need male role models': ' 28%', "If more kids are raised by gay parents, I worry that children may think it's OK to experiment with homosexuality": ' 23%', 'Children raised by gay parents would be teased and bullied at school': ' 21%', 'Pro-gay activists are trying to put their own agenda ahead of what is best for children': ' 19%', 'Allowing gay people to adopt will be the first step to allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry': ' 10%', 'All (Vol.)': '  2%', 'None (Vol.)': ' 18%', "Don't know/Refused": '  6%'}

source: Third Way Marriage Equality Survey, March 2009
sample: National likely voters including an oversample of blacks
question: Regardless of whether you support allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry, here are some arguments some people have made as to why they support allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry.  Please tell me which one or two arguments are most convincing to you....While some people do not approve of homosexuality, it is wrong for the government to tell people how to live their lives.  Marriage is about commitment and responsibility and gay couples should have the same rights and the same responsibilities as other couples.  Marriage is a stabilizing force that creates permanent relationships and a healthy society.  It is wrong for the law to treat people differently.  Marriage is a basic human right that should not be denied to gay and lesbian couples.

topic: ELECTIONS CONGRESS SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY REFORM
sample: National likely voters in Republican swing districts
question: Now I'm going to read you what the candidates for Congress are saying about gay marriage.  Regardless of who you would vote for, please tell me whether the Democratic statement or the Republican statement comes closer to your own view, even if neither is exactly right.  The Democratic candidate says, I believe we need to be fair and support granting civil unions to gay and lesbian couples, which grant many of the legal rights and responsibilities of married couples.  But I oppose a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage because decisions about marriage should be left to the states as they always have been.  This debate is important, but the Republican candidate for Congress is using it to divide our country and distract our attention from their lack of solutions to end the war in Iraq and fix our struggling economy.  The Republican candidate says, the recent decision by the California Supreme Court to legalize gay marriage is a big step that can lead to force other states to accept marriage between gay and lesbian couples.  We need a constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage and preserve the sanctity of marriage between a man and a woman.  Of course, this country faces a lot of other problems that need to be addressed, but our core values are under assault and it is a shame that Democrats are not standing up for American families. (If Democratic/Republican, ask:)(Do you feel that way strongly or somewhat?)
description:
Survey by Democracy Corps.
Methodology: Conducted by Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research, May 19 - May 26, 2008 and based on   1,600 telephone interviews. Sample: National likely voters in Republican swing districts. Likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2004 election/weren't registered/ineligible/too young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2008 election. [USGREEN.08DCMAY19.R62] (View Citation)
Topics: ELECTIONS CONGRESS SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY REFORM
Formal Citation
Democracy Corps. Democracy Corps Poll,
May, 2008 [survey question]. USGREEN.08DCMAY19.R62. Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Democratic statement strongly': ' 35%', 'Democratic statement somewhat': ' 18%', 'Republican statement somewhat': ' 11%', 'Republican statement strongly': ' 33%', "Don't know/Refused": '  5%'}

topic: ELECTIONS CONGRESS PARTIES TAXING SPENDING VALUES CRIME
question: Now, let me read you a statement from a Republican candidate for Congress.  After the statement please tell me whether this would make you much more likely, somewhat more likely, a little more likely, no more likely, or less likely to support the Republican candidate.  The Republican says, Democrats will move our country backward.  They support tax hikes that would increase the burden on middle class Americans and small businesses and favor more government spending that will increase the deficit.  Their liberal policies on abortion and gay marriage are our of touch with American values and they would make our country less secure by making it harder for our intelligence agencies to hunt down terrorists within the US.  Republicans will fight to keep taxes low, reduce the deficit and keep American safe from terrorism.  Does that make you much more likely, somewhat more likely, a little more likely, no more likely, or less likely to support this Republican candidate?

question: Which of those statements come closer to your own view, the Democratic statement or the Republican statement?...(Form E half sample, ask:)The Democrat says, we need a change of direction in Washington.  Both parties in Washington are too tied to special interests to make progress on the issues that affect average Americans.  The two parties are accomplishing nothing, but I will work to expand the research and development of alternative energy sources to reduce our dependence on foreign oil, reform the new prescription drug plan so that Medicare can negotiate lower drug prices for seniors and I will vote against any Congressional pay raise until the budget is balanced, (Form F half sample, ask:) The Democrat says, we need a change of direction in Washington.  President (George W.)Bush and the Republicans in Washington are too tied to special interests to make progress on the issues that affect average Americans.  President Bush and the Republicans are accomplishing nothing, but I will work to expand the research and development of alternative energy sources to reduce our dependence on foreign oil, reform the new prescription drug plan so that Medicare can negotiate lower drug prices for seniors and I will vote against any Congressional pay raise until the budget is balanced, The Republican says, Democrats will move our country backward.  They support tax hikes that would increase the burden on middle class Americans and small businesses and favor more government spending that will increase the deficit.  Their liberal policies on abortion and gay marriage are our of touch with American values and they would make our country less secure by making it harder for our intelligence agencies to hunt down terrorists within the US.  Republicans will fight to keep taxes low, reduce the deficit and keep American safe from terrorism. (If Democratic/Republican statement, ask:)(Do you feel that way strongly or not strongly?)

topic: ELECTIONS CONGRESS PARTIES FAMILY SEX GROUPS EQUALITY ECONOMICS
question: (Now, I'd like to read you a pair of statements from a Democrat and Republican candidate for Congress.  After hearing the statements, regardless of how you plan to vote, please tell me which statement you agree with more.  The Republican says, our country faces many threats, but few threaten us as much as the breakdown of the family unit and the liberal effort to overturn laws defining marriage as the union of a man and a woman.  In Congress, I will fight to lower taxes and decrease government regulation so that individual Americans can prosper, but I will never forget that we cannot prosper if we sacrifice our moral foundation.  The Democrat says, there are a lot of things that need to be changed in this country, but marriage is not one of them.  I oppose gay marriage, but I'm not running for Congress to stop gay marriage.  I'm running because we need to clean up the mess in Washington and focus on the issues that affect all Americans--reduce health care costs, decrease our dependence on foreign oil, and create jobs here at home.  Which statement do you agree with more, the statement from the Democratic candidate or the statement from the Republican candidate?)(If Democrat/Republican, ask:)Do you feel strongly about that or not so strongly?

topic: ELECTIONS CONGRESS PARTIES FAMILY SEX GROUPS EQUALITY ECONOMICS
question: (Now, I'd like to read you a pair of statements from a Democrat and Republican candidate for Congress.  After hearing the statements, regardless of how you plan to vote, please tell me which statement you agree with more.  The Republican says, our country faces many threats, but few threaten us as much as the breakdown of the family unit and the liberal effort to overturn laws defining marriage as the union of a man and a woman.  In Congress, I will fight to lower taxes and decrease government regulation so that individual Americans can prosper, but I will never forget that we cannot prosper if we sacrifice our moral foundation.  The Democrat says, politicians like to focus on issues that divide us, like gay marriage, but I say 'who cares?' I don?t want the government in Washington telling two consenting adults whether they can marry anymore than I want it telling people whether they can own a gun or how they should worship.  Gay marriage is not my priority.  My priorities are reducing health care costs, decreasing our dependence on foreign oil, and creating jobs here at home.  Which statement do you agree with more, the statement from the Democratic candidate or the statement from the Republican candidate?)(If Democrat/Republican, ask:)Do you feel strongly about that or not so strongly?

topic: PARTIES ELECTIONS SEX GROUPS EQUALITY FAMILY
question: (Now, I am going to read you what some people say are some differences between Republicans and Democrats.  For each, please tell me if it is a difference that makes you much more likely to vote for a Republican candidate, a difference that makes you somewhat more likely to vote for a Republican candidate, a difference that doesn't make you any more likely to vote for a Republican candidate, or is it not a real difference between Republicans and Democrats.)...Democrats support legalizing gay marriage and blocked Congress from protecting the family.  Republicans will defend the sanctity of marriage.
description:
Survey by Democracy Corps.
Methodology: Conducted by Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research, June 20 - June 25, 2005 and based on   1,078 telephone interviews. Sample: National likely voters. National likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2004 presidential election/weren't registered/ineligible/to young to vote and said they are probably or almost certain to vote in the 2006 election. topic: VOTE FOR PRESIDENT LEADERS CONGRESS PRESIDENCY SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
question: (Now, let me read you a series of statements by John Kerry.  After each statement please tell me whether this would make you much more likely, somewhat more likely, a little more likely, no more likely, or less likely to support John Kerry in this year's (2004 Presidential)election.)...George (W.)Bush is using the gay marriage issue to avoid having to defend his record in Iraq, jobs and health care.  The truth is, Bush is pushing to amend the U.S. (United States)Constitution to bar gay marriage, but that is just politics.  I believe the states should be allowed to define marriage, as they always have.  My goal is to focus on issues that impact families now, like keeping jobs in the U.S., making health care affordable for all, and focusing our resources on building a stronger America.

topic: VOTE FOR PRESIDENT LEADERS CONGRESS PRESIDENCY SEX GROUPS FAMILY EQUALITY
question: Now, let me read you a series of statements by John Kerry.  After each statement please tell me whether this would make you much more likely, somewhat more likely, a little more likely, no more likely, or less likely to support John Kerry in this year's (2004 Presidential)election....George (W.)Bush is using the gay marriage issue to avoid having to defend his record in Iraq, jobs and health care.  The truth is, I oppose gay marriage and have consistently said that marriage should remain between a man and woman.  Bush is pushing to amend the U.S. (United States)Constitution to bar gay marriage, but that is just politics.  I believe the states should be allowed to define marriage, as they always have.  My goal to focus on issues that impact families now, like keeping jobs in the U.S., making health care affordable for all, and focusing our resources on building a stronger America.

topic: LEADERS CONGRESS FAMILY SEX GROUPS EQUALITY REFORM VALUES
question: (Let me read you some statements about John Kerry.  For each statement, please tell me whether this description, if accurate, raises very serious doubts, serious doubts, minor doubts or no real doubts in your own mind about John Kerry.)...The American family is under so much pressure, but Kerry's beliefs and plans undermine the best efforts of parents.  Just last year, the U.S. (United States)Senate voted that no state had to accept the gay marriages legalized in other states.  But John Kerry was one of only 14 Senators to vote against states being able to protect the institution of marriage.  Now, Kerry is leading the forces opposed to a constitutional amendment that would define marriage as between a man and a woman.  These are not the right priorities and values for our country today....Does that raise very serious doubts, serious doubts, minor doubts or no real doubts in your own mind about John Kerry?

topic: HISPANICS VOTE FOR PRESIDENT VALUES ABORTION RELIGION FAMILY
question: (Now, let me read you a series of statements by George (W.)Bush.  After each statement tell whether this would make you much more likely, somewhat more likely, a little more likely, no more likely, or less likely to support George Bush in this year's (2004 Presidential)election.)...Bush says, America is a great country because of our commitment to family and our strong faith.  I have fought to restore honor and dignity to the White House and to provide steady leadership during these times of change.  But John Kerry wants to take our country in a different direction and turns his back on our traditional values.  Kerry's support for abortion has put him in conflict with the Catholic church, and he refuses to stand up for the sanctity of the American family as his state becomes the first in the nation to legalize gay marriage.  His values reflect the wrong priorities for this country....Would this make you much more likely, somewhat more likely, a little more likely, no more likely, or less likely to support George W. Bush?
description:
Survey by Democracy Corps.
Methodology: Conducted by Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research, July 14 - July 22, 2004 and based on   1,000 telephone interviews. Sample: National Hispanic registered likely voters. National Hispanic registered likely voters are Hispanic registered voters who voted in the 2000 Presidential election/were ineligible/too young to vote or who didn't vote in the 2000 election but did vote in the 2002 Congressional election, and they will probably or are almost certain to vote in the 2004 Presidential election. [USGREEN.04DCJLH.R81] (View Citation)
Topics: HISPANICS VOTE FOR PRESIDENT VALUES ABORTION RELIGION FAMILY
Formal Citation
Democracy Corps. Democracy Corps Poll,
Jul, 2004 [survey question]. USGREEN.04DCJLH.R81. Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research [producer].
Cornell University, Ithaca, NY: Roper Center for Public Opinion Research, iPOLL [distributor], accessed Aug-14-2017.
Acknowledgement
The survey results reported here were obtained from searches of the iPOLL Databank and other resources provided by the Roper
Center for Public Opinion Research.
results: {'Much more likely': ' 27%', 'Somewhat more likely': ' 11%', 'Little more likely': ' 11%', 'No more likely': ' 17%', 'Less likely': ' 30%', "Don't know/Refused": '  4%'}

question: (Now I'm going to read you some pairs of statements.  As I read each pair, please tell me whether the first statement or the second statement comes closer to your own views, even if neither is exactly right.)...The legalization of gay marriages in some states is not nearly as important as other issues, like health care and job losses, that affect the family.  The legalization of gay marriages in some states seriously undermines the family and makes it much harder for parents to teach their children the right thing.  Which statement comes closer to your own view? (If First/Second statement, ask:)Do you feel strongly about that, or not so strongly?
description:
Survey by Democracy Corps.
Methodology: Conducted by Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research, June 14 - June 17, 2004 and based on   1,007 telephone interviews. Sample: National registered likely voters. National registered likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2000 presidential election/were in eligible/too young to vote or who didn't vote in the 2000 election but voted in the 2002 election and they said they will probably or are almost certain to vote in the 2004 presidential election. question: On the issue of gay marriage and civil unions... which means homosexual couples can form legal unions with some of the same rights of married couple...For whom would you vote (for president 2004)if you heard the following statements from George W. Bush and John Kerry? George W. Bush says he believes marriage is the union of one man and one woman. We should continue to recognize heterosexual marriage as ensuring, promoting, and supporting a tested social structure for the bearing and raising of children. Bush says we must remember though the same moral tradition that defines marriage also teaches us that each individual has dignity and value in God's sight. While Bush says different states should have the freedom to allow civil unions, because judges in states like Massachusetts insist on legalizing gay marriage, the courts have left no choice and Bush therefore supports an amendment to the Constitution that defends the sanctity of marriage. John Kerry says he is opposed to gay marriage. We should maintain marriage as a union of a man and a woman, but we do need a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriages where the federal government dictates what people must do. Our states have always handled the question of marriage. Kerry says he personally hopes states bar gay marriage but allow civil unions, where partners can at least be allowed the same health care benefits, visitation rights and inheritance. Kerry says, it is sad that the president, apparently for political reasons, is promoting this amendment, instead of addressing the problem of jobs and health care. After hearing these statements, would you vote for George W. Bush or John Kerry? (If Undecided/Other candidate/Refused, ask:)Well, if the election for president were held today and you had to decide right now, to which candidate would you lean--Republican George Bush or the Democrat John Kerry?

question: As you may know, there is a proposal in Congress to amend the U.S. (United States)Constitution to make same-sex marriages illegal. Supporters of this proposed amendment say that it is a serious attempt to address the issue of gay marriage. Opponents of this proposed amendment say that it is being promoted only for political, election-year purposes. Whom do you agree with more--supporters of the amendment, or opponents of the amendment?

conducted_by: Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research/Public Opinion Strategies
topic: SEX GROUPS FAMILY VALUES EQUALITY REFORM
question: (Now I am going to read you some pairs of statements. As I read each pair, please tell me whether the first statement, or the second statement comes closer to your owns views, even if neither is exactly right.)...George W. Bush says he believes marriage is the union of one man and one woman. We should continue to recognize heterosexual marriage as ensuring, promoting, and supporting a tested social structure for the bearing and raising of children. Bush says we must remember though the same moral tradition that defines marriage also teaches us each individual has dignity and value in God's sight. While Bush says different states should have the freedom to allow civil unions, because judges in states like Massachusetts insist on legalizing gay marriage, the courts have left no choice and Bush therefore supports an amendment to the Constitution that defends the sanctity of marriage. John Kerry says he is opposed to gay marriage. We should maintain marriage as a union of a man and a woman, but we do not need a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriages where the federal government dictates what people must do. Our states have always handled the question of marriage. Kerry says he personally hopes states bar gay marriage but allow civil unions, where partners can at least be allowed the same health care benefits, visitation rights and inheritance. Kerry says, it is sad that the president, apparently for political reasons, is promoting this amendment, instead of addressing the problem of jobs and health care.

question: Now I'd like to read you what John Kerry says about the (2004)election with President (George W.)Bush. The Republicans are attacking my values and questioning my patriotism, but I served my country proudly in Vietnam and value the veterans who rally to me now. Apparently, President Bush wants an election about gay marriage, and I'm opposed to that. I believe in tolerance and diversity. But I challenge the irresponsibility and values of those at the top who run up huge deficits and pass on the bills to our children. I challenge CEO's (Chief Executive Officers)who get big tax breaks and defense contracts, while shipping U.S. (United States)jobs overseas. So, I welcome an election where we talk about restoring our values and sense of loyalty. Now, once again, after hearing that, if the election for President were held today for whom would you vote--Republican George (W.)Bush or Democrat John Kerry? (If Other/Undecided/Refused, ask:)Well if the election for president were held today and you had to decide right now, to which candidate would you lean--Republican George (W.)Bush or Democrat John Kerry?
description:
Survey by Democracy Corps.
Methodology: Conducted by Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research, February 10 - February 15, 2004 and based on   1,010 telephone interviews. Sample: National registered likely voters (see note). National registered likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2000 presidential election/were ineligible/too young to vote or who didn't vote in the 2000 election but did vote in the 2002 election and said they will probably vote or are almost certain to vote in the 2004 presidential election. question: Now I'd like to read you what John Kerry says about the (2004)election with President (George W.)Bush. The Republicans are attacking my values and questioning my patriotism, but I served my country proudly in Vietnam and value the veterans who rally to me now. Apparently, President Bush wants an election about gay marriage, and I'm opposed to that. I believe in tolerance and diversity. But we need big change in America, so ordinary citizens, not corporations, get heard in Washington. We need to create jobs and get health care costs under control. Rather than more tax cuts for the very richest and exploding deficits, we need improved education and a secure retirement. So, I welcome an election about how we best take care of America. Now, once again, after hearing that, if the election for President were held today for whom would you vote--Republican George (W.)Bush or Democrat John Kerry? (If Other/Undecided/Refused, ask:)Well if the election for president were held today and you had to decided right now, to which candidate would you lean--Republican George (W.)Bush or Democrat John Kerry?

topic: CONGRESS LEADERS IDEOLOGY VALUES SEX GROUPS FAMILY ABORTION CRIME EQUALITY
question: (Let me read you some statements about John Kerry. For each statement, please tell me whether this description, if accurate, raises very serious doubts, serious doubts, minor doubts or no real doubts in your own mind about John Kerry.)...John Kerry does not represent mainstream values of our society. Kerry is a Massachusetts liberal whose state has become the first in the nation to legalize gay marriage. He oppose capital punishment and tougher sentencing for violent criminals but supports expanded welfare programs and higher taxes. He supports partial-birth abortion, gay rights, and affirmative action but opposes the Second Amendment. Kerry does not share mainstream American values and will lead our country in the wrong direction.

question: (Now I'm going to read you some statements.  As I read each pair, please tell me whether the first statement or the second statement comes closer to your own views, even if neither is exactly right.)...First statement: By barring civil unions, Republicans are using government to dictate the personal and private choices people make about their families and denying people their equal rights.  We should respect people's fundamental right to privacy and afford all families the same rights.  Second statement: By championing civil unions, Democrats are moving too far, too fast to change thousands of years of how we think about and define what is meant by marriage.  Our country should be tolerant and you can respect people's right to privacy without demanding and promoting a new right for gay marriage. (If First/Second statement, ask:)Do you feel strongly about that or not so strongly?

question: (Now I'm going to read you some statements.  As I read each pair, please tell me whether the first statement or the second statement comes closer to your own views, even if neither is exactly right.)...First statement: Some Democrats say allowing same sex couples to enter into civil unions help make sure that everyone in this country has equal rights and is treated with the same dignity and respect.  Same sex couples, who are in committed relationships, should be afforded the same rights as married couples such as access to healthcare and retirement benefits and inheritance.  Second statement: Some Republicans say we should think of marriage as being between a man and a woman.  Any obstacle the gay community faces can be addressed by changing legislation to make sure that people and their partners are eligible for benefits regardless of marital status.  We do not need to change the common definition of how we think about marriage. (If First/Second statement, ask:)Do you feel strongly about that or not so strongly?

question: Now I'm going to read you some statements.  As I read each pair, please tell me whether the first statement or the second statement comes closer to your own views, even if neither is exactly right....First statement: Some Democrats say allowing same sex couples to enter into civil unions help make sure that everyone in this country has equal rights and is treated with the same dignity and respect.  Same sex couples, who are in committed relationships, should be afforded the same rights as married couples such as access to healthcare and retirement benefits and inheritance.  Second statement: Some Republicans say we should think of marriage as being between a man and a woman.  Republicans say there is little difference between calling it a civil union and gay marriage.  We should continue to recognize heterosexual marriage as ensuring, promoting, and supporting a tested social structure for the bearing and raising of children. (If First/Second statement, ask:)Do you feel strongly about that or not so strongly?

Methodology: Conducted by

question: Now, I'd like to read you the descriptions of two fictitious men--call them Mr. A. and Mr. B. Suppose for a moment that you had to select one or the other as the nominee of your party for President of the United States. Here are their descriptions: Mr. A. is about 55 years old, he was born and raised in New York City, he is married with two children and has a business background. Mr. B. is about 60 years old, he was born and raised in the middle west, he has never married--there have even been rumors that he might be a homosexual--and his career has been as an attorney. Which man would you choose, Mr. A. or Mr. B.?

question: Every family has different experiences these days.
